revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1863 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Base Ball Players]] champion – [[Brooklyn Eckfords]] '''Events''' * The champion [[Brooklyn Eckfords|Eckford]] club of [[Brooklyn, New York]] wins all ten matches against [[NABBP|National Association]] members, a run that began in August 1862
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 5 May — [[Joe Coburn]] defeats [[Mike McCoole]] after 67 rounds and is now widely recognised as American Champion.<ref name="JC">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/coburn.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Joe Coburn]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 10 December — [[Tom King (boxer)|Tom King]] defeats [[John C. Heenan]] in the 24th round to retain the English Championship title.<ref name="TK">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/king-t.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom King]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> This is Heenan's final fight.<ref name="JH">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/heenan.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John C. Heenan]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 8 January — formation of [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club]] out of the Sheffield Match Fund Committee that has been established in 1861. Yorkshire CCC plays its initial first-class match v. [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] at [[The Oval]] on 4, 5 & 6 June. It is a rain-affected draw, evenly balanced. * 12 August — formation of [[Hampshire County Cricket Club]]. A number of previous county organisations including the famous [[Hambledon Club]] have existed in Hampshire during the previous hundred years or more, but none have survived indefinitely. * 15 December — formation of [[Middlesex County Cricket Club]] at a meeting in the London Tavern. * An organisation in Cheltenham is believed to have been the forerunner of [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club]], which has definitely been founded by 1871. Exact details of the club's foundation have been lost. '''England''' * Most runs – [[Will Mortlock]] 736 @ 26.28 (HS 106) * Most wickets – [[George Wootton]] 87 @ 9.74 (BB 8–9)
==[[Football]]== '''Rules''' * 26 October — foundation by local clubs of [[the Football Association]] (FA) in London. The first set of Laws is drafted, based mainly on the [[Cambridge Rules|Cambridge University Rules]]. The purpose is to regulate English football under a single code of rules, but the [[rugby football]] clubs do not join because of the ball handling issue. Their attempt at compromise between the "dribbling" and "handling" codes is rejected by the dribblers and so rugby football becomes in time an entirely separate sport. The FA rules establish [[association football]] (''aka'' football or "soccer") as a distinct sport. * Apart from their main purpose of introducing standard rules of play and procedure, the Laws seek to differentiate between association football and rugby football. The essential difference in the two codes is encapsulated in Laws 9 and 11 which state that no (outfield) player shall run with the ball (in his hands) and that no (outfield) player shall throw the ball or pass it to another with his hands. The Laws will be amended later to clarify the situation at throw ins and during possession by goalkeepers but the FA is emphatic from the start that "hand ball" is illegal during normal play. * These Laws are originally known as the "London Rules" because they are only adopted by some London clubs and hardly anywhere else. Several clubs exist in Sheffield at the time and they play to the so–called [[Sheffield Rules]]. Gradually the FA, led by [[C. W. Alcock|Charles Alcock]], manages to persuade the clubs that a uniform set of rules is desirable and, after many adaptations and compromises, the FA rules eventually become standard. * The rejection of handling causes the "Rugby rules" clubs and colleges to withdraw from the FA and they will eventually found the [[Rugby Football Union]] in 1871. '''Clubs founded''' * Probable foundation of [[Stoke City]] as Stoke Ramblers, although it is not known to have played any matches until 1868. If founded in 1863, it is the second oldest senior professional club playing association football after [[Notts County]]. * Foundation of the original Bradford Football Club, playing rugby rules, which in 1907 will become [[Bradford Park Avenue A.F.C.]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1863 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Willie Park, Snr.|Willie Park senior]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1863 Grand National|Grand National]] – Emblem * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Lady Augusta * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Macaroni (horse)|Macaroni]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Macaroni * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Queen Bertha * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Lord Clifden]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Banker '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Touchstone
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 28 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 20th [[The Boat Race 1863|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Besa Stadium | image = [[Image:Stadiumi Besa.jpg|290px]] | location = Rr. Vangjel Thanasi 7
[[Kavajë]], [[Albania]] | coordinates = {{Coord|41|11|18.81|N|19|33|11.69|E|display=inline,title}} | owner = Bashkia Kavajë | broke_ground = 1968 | opened = 26 April 1974 | expanded = 1988-1990 | renovated = | construction_cost = | surface = Grass | field_shape = Elliptical | architect = Isuf Sukaj, Mehmet Qarri | structural engineer = Agim Koçi, Nikolla Verdho | tenants = [[Besa Kavajë]]
[[Kavajë|Bashkia Kavajë]] | seating_capacity = 8,000 | seating_type = | dimensions = 105 x 70m | record_attendance = }} '''Besa Stadium''' ({{lang-sq|Stadiumi Besa}}) is a football [[stadium]] in [[Kavajë]], [[Albania]]. It is the home ground of [[Besa Kavajë]]. The stadium has a full [[seating capacity]] of about 8,000.[http://www.worldstadiums.com/europe/countries/albania.shtml From World Stadiums][https://int.soccerway.com/teams/albania/ks-besa-kavaje/75/venue/ Soccerway] ==History== Project for the construction of a new stadium in Kavajë began as early as 1968. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Football venues in Albania}} [[Category:Besa Kavajë]] [[Category:Sports venues in Kavajë]] [[Category:Football venues in Albania]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Albania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1974]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Albania]] {{Albania-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} A '''chicken wing tackle''' is a move in [[Australian rules football]] and [[rugby league]], in which a player locks an opponent's arm so that he or she cannot legally move the ball. It is a controversial move that has injured players and resulted in fines for players performing the tackle. The phrase was coined by Fox Sports NRL Producer Geoff Bullock (a.k.a. Bluey) in 2008. <ref name="guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2008/apr/16/rugbyleague.sport|title=Newton fined over chicken wing|last=Walker|first=Gareth|date=2008-04-16|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-05-26|location=London}}</ref>
==Rugby league== [[Melbourne Storm]] forward [[Adam Blair]] was found guilty of committing a chicken wing tackle in an Australian Rugby League match against [[Brisbane Broncos]] in April 2008.<ref name="guardian" /> A former Storm player, [[Clint Newton]] of [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] in the [[Super League]] was fined £300 after performing the tackle, with a disciplinary panel finding him guilty of "behaviour contrary to the true spirit of the game by making a dangerous tackle".<ref name="guardian" />
==Australian rules football== The use of the chicken wing tackle in the [[Australian Football League]] is generally considered to have been picked up from [[National Rugby League]].<ref name="pluck">{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/sport/afl/story/0,26576,25402009-19742,00.html |title=AFL may pluck out 'wing' tackle after Brent Harvey injury |last=Ralph |first=Jon |date=2009-04-28 |publisher=Herald Sun |accessdate=2009-05-26}}</ref> It became a controversy after Kangaroos' skipper [[Brent Harvey]] was chicken winged in 2009 during an Australian football match and suffered a dislocated elbow that caused him to miss months of play.<ref name="Paltry">{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/tabid/208/default.aspx?newsid=76042|title=Chicken wing tackle a paltry issue|last=Phelan|first=Jason|author2=Ben Broad|date=1 May 2009|work=AFL BigPond Network|accessdate=2009-05-24}}</ref> The tackle has been furiously slammed by some saying it must be banned. AFL umpires manager Jeff Gieschen is confident the practice is not about to become commonplace.<ref name="Paltry"/>
In July 2012, Carlton captain Chris Judd was involved in another "chicken wing tackle" controversy, in a game against North Melbourne.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/paltry-hope-for-carlton-after-judds-chicken-wing-20120714-2235v.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Paltry hope for Carlton after Judd's 'chicken wing'}}</ref> North player Leigh Adams had been tackled by another player, and was lying on the ground, as Judd grabbed his arm and pulled it backwards in the 'chicken wing' style.<ref>http://www.afl.com.au/video/tabid/76/contentid/468627/judd+wings+adams/default.aspx</ref> Judd was widely criticized in the media for this action and was cited for misconduct by the Match Review Panel. He was subsequently suspended for 4 games by the tribunal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/141468/default.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717033130/http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/141468/default.aspx |archivedate=17 July 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = DeltaPlex Arena | nickname = | logo_image = DeltaPlex_Arena.jpg | image = Deltaplex.JPG | image_size = 250px | fullname = DeltaPlex Arena & Conference Center | address = 2500 Turner Avenue | location = [[Walker, Michigan]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|0|31|N|85|40|54|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1952 | opened = | renovated = 1998 | closed = | owner = Joel Langlois | operator = | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | former_names = Grand Rapids Stadium
Stadium Arena
Turner Arena | tenants = [[Grand Rapids Rockets]] ([[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|IHL]]) (1952–1956)
[[Grand Rapids Owls (1977–80)|Grand Rapids Owls]] (IHL) (1977–1980)
[[Grand Rapids Hoops]] ([[Continental Basketball Association|CBA]]) (2001–2003)
[[Grand Rapids Flight]] ([[International Basketball League|IBL]]) (2008)
[[West Michigan ThunderHawks]] ([[Indoor Football League|IFL]]) (2010)
[[Grand Rapids Drive]] ([[NBA G League]]) (2014–present) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 5,000
Concerts: 7,000 | dimensions = | website = {{URL|http://deltaplex.com/|Venue Website}} | publictransit = }} '''DeltaPlex Arena & Conference Center''' (formerly '''Grand Rapids Stadium''', '''Stadium Arena''', and '''Turner Arena''') is a 5,000-seat multipurpose [[arena]] in [[Walker, Michigan]], United States. It is the home of the [[Grand Rapids Drive]] of the [[NBA G League]]. It was built in 1952 and since then the DeltaPlex sports, entertainment and convention complex has grown around the arena. The arena is a {{convert|23000|sqft|m2|-3|adj=mid}} space, which has a {{convert|52|ft|m|0|adj=on}} ceiling, seats up to 7,000 for [[concerts]] and has 1,088 loge seats. It has a 60-by-56-foot portable stage. DeltaPlex Arena is a venue usable for not only sports and concerts but also trade shows, conventions and other events.[http://deltaplex.com/files/2012/09/DeltaPlex-Information.pdf The DeltaPlex Arena & Conference Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819084559/http://deltaplex.com/files/2012/09/DeltaPlex-Information.pdf |date=2014-08-19 }} deltaplex.com, June 18, 2014 ==History== The original building was constructed in 1952, and began life as the Stadium Arena. The building had an arched roof design with wooded arch supports instead of steel. The building housed many different tenants including two defunct IHL Hockey teams. The [[Grand Rapids Rockets]] in the 1950s and the [[Grand Rapids Owls (1977–80)|Grand Rapids Owls]] in the late 1970s until 1980. During the 1960s and early 1970s it was home to Alantic Mills Department Store. It was also home for a short time to a drive-in theater, known as the Stadium Drive-In Theater. For most of its life it was located at the corner of Turner Ave. and West River Drive. However, due to a reconstruction of West River Drive, the parking lot was enlarged and Turner Ave. ended at West River Drive. It was the Grand Rapids area's main indoor entertainment facility until the construction of [[Van Andel Arena]] in 1995. In the mid-1990s the building was sold to the Langlois Family. After the purchase an extensive, ground-up restoration and remodeling regimen followed and the newly christened DeltaPlex was born. The arena serves as the Grand Rapids chapter of [[Arena Racing]]. The DeltaPlex Arena also previously hosted the [[Grand Rapids Flight]] of the [[International Basketball League]] in 2008. In 2010, it was home to the [[West Michigan ThunderHawks]] of the [[Indoor Football League]]. The DeltaPlex is currently home of the [[Detroit Pistons]]' [[NBA G League]] affiliate, the [[Grand Rapids Drive]].{{cite web | url=http://www.nba.com/dleague/news/nba_dleague_comes_to_grand_rapids_2014_04_15.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416060331/http://www.nba.com/dleague/news/nba_dleague_comes_to_grand_rapids_2014_04_15.html | dead-url=yes | archive-date=April 16, 2014 | title=NBA D-League Comes to Grand Rapids for 2014-15 Season | publisher=NBA Development League | date=April 15, 2014 | accessdate=April 15, 2014 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.deltaplex.com Official Site] {{NBA G League arenas}} [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Kent County, Michigan]] [[Category:Convention centers in Michigan]] [[Category:Grand Rapids Drive]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Michigan]] [[Category:NBA G League arenas]] [[Category:Sports venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1952]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Kent County, Michigan]] [[Category:1952 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Continental Basketball Association venues]]

{{Use Australian English|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox AFL biography | name = Dick Telford | image = | fullname = Dick Telford | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|4|2|df=y}} | birth_place = Melbourne | death_date = | death_place = | originalteam = Northcote Park | height = 175 cm | weight = 70 kg | position = Centreman | statsend = 1967 | years1 = 1966 | club1 = [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] | games_goals1 = 1 (0) | years2 = 1967 | club2 = [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] | games_goals2 = 2 (0) | games_goalstotal = 3 (0) | careerhighlights = }} '''Richard David Telford''' [[Order of Australia|AM]]<ref name=honour>{{cite web|title=Richard David Telford|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/|work=It's An Honour|accessdate=22 February 2013}}</ref> (born 2 April 1945)<ref name=afl>{{cite web|title=Dick Telford|url=http://afltables.com/afl/stats/players/D/Dick_Telford.html|work=AFL Stats Website|accessdate=22 February 2013}}</ref> is a former [[Australian rules football]]er who played for [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] and [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] in the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] (VFL) during the 1960s, although he mainly played reserves. He went on to become as a leading Australian sport scientist and distance running coach. He was the first sport scientist employed by the [[Australian Institute of Sport]] (AIS).
==Personal== He was born 2 April 1945 in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]].<ref name=afl/> Telford's primary school days were at College Rural, a small Melbourne Teacher's College practising school in the grounds of the [[University of Melbourne]]. His father (also named Dick) had returned from World War 2 and was studying for a B.Sc at the university, hence the connection with the university primary school. He attended [[Northcote High School]].<ref name=darebin>{{cite web|title=Richard Telford |url=http://dhe.darebin-libraries.vic.gov.au/encyclopedia.asp?id=760 |work=Darebin Historical Encyclopedia |accessdate=22 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130423090512/http://dhe.darebin-libraries.vic.gov.au/encyclopedia.asp?id=760 |archivedate=23 April 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> He is married to Sue and they have two children.
==Sporting career== Telford never played a game of competitive football or cricket through primary school as the school was too small to field a team. This all changed when he went to Northcote High School where his football and cricket blossomed. He played his junior football with North Reservoir.<ref name=darebin/> He was invited to train with [[Fitzroy Cricket Club]] as a 16-year-old and at 17 he was invited to train with [[Collingwood Football Club]]. He won 3rd Best and Fairest for Collingwood Reserves team, playing on the wing, but due to the competitiveness of the team he made just one appearance in the seniors, a win over [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne Football Club]] at Lake Oval, a debut he shared with [[Doug Searl]]. The following year, he transferred to [[Fitzroy Football Club]] and after playing well in the Reserves, he again won a place in the senior team, this time as a rover, but after two games was ruled out for the rest of the season with a badly damaged hand.
A natural centreman, Telford was never given a chance to play this position in the VFL but transferred to [[Northern Bullants|Preston]] in 1968.<ref name=darebin/> Coach [[Allan Joyce]] immediately recognised his ability and selected him in the centre for the senior team after seeing him play one game in the reserves. Telford won that season's [[J.J. Liston Trophy]], Best and Fairest Player [[Victorian Football Association]], the club Best Player Award, and Preston won the Premiership.<ref name=darebin/> The following year, he won the club Best Player Award and the Preston the premiership. Telford retired in 1972 after 68 VFA games, by which time he had secured two club 'best and fairest' and participated in back to back premierships, in 1968 and 1969.<ref name=darebin/><ref name=aflcom>{{cite web|title=Dick Telford|url=http://australianfootball.com/players/player/dick+telford/9837|work=Australian Football.com|accessdate=22 February 2013}}</ref> Telford spent the 1975 and 1976 seasons as non playing coach of Preston after returning from Western Australia.<ref name=darebin/>
Through his football career, Telford played cricket, and appeared in 21 first XI [[Victorian Premier Cricket|district cricket]] matches between 1964/65 and 1968/69 for [[Melbourne University Cricket Club|University]] and Fitzroy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://premier.cricketvictoria.com.au/files/3/files/player-register-career-stats/VCA%201st%20XI%20CAREER%20RECORDS%201889-90%20to%202014-15%20S-Z.pdf|title=VCA 1st XI Career records 1889-90 to 2014-15, S-Z|accessdate=26 February 2016|publisher=Cricket Victoria}}</ref>
Telford was a world class veterans runner.<ref name=lenton>{{cite journal|last=Lenton|first=Brian|title=The man behind the breakfast cereal adds|journal=Fun Runner|date=June–July 1990|volume=12|issue=2|pages=33–34}}</ref> He competed in the Melbourne Marathon in 1978 and recorded a time 3 hours 12 minutes, and following 5 other marathons recorded a personal best time of 2 hour 27 minutes.<ref name=lenton/> In 1984, he turned to the track and he won his first Australian veterans M40 1500m championship in 1985. At the 1987 World Veterans Games in Melbourne he tied for third in the 1500m.<ref name=lenton/> He has the unusual personal achievement of recording personal his career personal best times in the 800 (1.58), 1500 (3.57), 5k, 10k, half marathon (1 hour 9 minutes) and marathon (2 hours 27 minutes)in his very last races in these events. Te
==Academic and Research Career== On leaving Northcote High School in 1962, Telford pursued his love of sport and physical education and completed a Diploma in Physical Education and Trained Secondary Teachers' Certificate at [[University of Melbourne]] to begin a teaching career at Glenroy Technical School in 1966. He soon found there was more to learn and following advice from good friend Ross Price, (North Melbourne footballer and University of Melbourne 1st grade cricketer) Telford went on to complete a BSc (Hons). Not wishing to leave Australia as did some of his colleagues, Telford pursued postgraduate work at his "home away from home" University of Melbourne (he went to Primary School there as well) and in 1976 completed a Master of Science at the [[University of Melbourne]], with his thesis titled ''The maximal aerobic power and related studies in sedentary subjects and endurance athletes from Melbourne''. In 1979, his PhD thesis titled ''Cardiorespiratory properties of trained and untrained subjects and specificity of athletic performance evaluation'' was completed at the University of Melbourne. He then worked as a lecturer in the Physical Education Department at Preston Institute of Technology.<ref name=darebin/>
After leaving the AIS in 2005, Telford returned to his research passion. He took up positions as Research Director of the Lifestyle of Our Kids (LOOK) Project, [[Commonwealth Institute]], Adjunct Professor at the [[Australian National University]] College of Medicine, Biology and Environment and Research Fellow at the [[Canberra Hospital]]'s Clinical Trials Unit.<ref name=anu/> The four-year LOOK study of 734 otherwise healthy Australian children in the general community, aged between 8 and 12 years, has found that the main difference between lean and overweight children was that lean children were more physically active. The study provides important evidence in the childhood obesity debate.<ref name=anu>{{cite web|title=Physical activity key to healthy kids|url=http://news.anu.edu.au/2012/11/22/physical-activity-key-to-healthy-kids/|work=Australian National University News, 22 November 2012|accessdate=22 February 2013}}</ref>
==Sport Scientist Career== Whilst studying for his PhD, Telford was invited to look after the [[Victorian cricket team|Victorian Sheffield Shield Cricket team]] as Manager and Coaching Coordinator. During his time with the team, it won back to back [[Sheffield Shield]]'s in 1978/9 and 1979/80 as well as the One-day competition.<ref name=darebin/>
In 1980, Telford was the first sport scientist appointed to the newly established [[Australian Institute of Sport]]. He was appointed to the position of Co-ordinator of Sports Sciences and Physiologist. Telford was required to develop the philosophy, select major positions in sports medicine, physical therapy, psychology and biomechanics areas, develop sports science and medicine services and develop a plan for future facilities. [[John Bloomfield (academic)|John Bloomfield]] stated Telford was an excellent choice to establish sports science at the AIS as he was a talented [[exercise physiologist]] as well as competent distance running coach. Telford appointed [[Robert De Castella]], as a sport science technician and he later went on to become a world class marathon runner. Telford was appointed team physiologist for the Australian swim team at the [[1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Los Angeles Olympics]]. Telford expanded physiological services to include nutrition services and as the sport science medicine staffing expanded he was appointed Head of Applied Physiology and Nutrition. Telford played a major role in raising the profile of the AIS and sports science through the development and advertising promotion of two products. In 1986, [[Kellogg's]] launched the ''Sustain'' breakfast cereal, Telford played a major role and was prominent in television advertisements.<ref name=lenton/> In 1988, Telford and AIS nutritionist Vicki Deakin worked with [[Goodman Fielders]] to develop the ''Gold Medal'' bread. During his time in charge of AIS Physiology, the AIS undertook major research into nutrition, heat, altitude and talent identification. His philosophy was " I always considered the coaches to be my boss. You were trying to help the coach get the best out on an athlete". He left as Head of AIS Physiology to take up a distance running coaching role with AIS Track and Field. He was replaced by [[Allan Hahn]].
==Distance Running Coach== Telford became involved in distance running coaching in the 1980s. He was the physiologist to the World Champion marathoner Rob de Castella and coached [[Lisa Martin]] (Ondieki), to a silver medal in the women's marathon at the [[1988 Summer Olympics|1988 Seoul Olympics]]. Martin is currently Australia's only Olympic marathon medallist. He became a full-time distance running coach in 1994 when appointed to run the AIS distance running program. He continued in this role until 2005 when the AIS and [[Athletics Australia]] decided to discontinue the program. Telford has continued to coach privately. Leading Australian distance runners coached by Telford include - Commonwealth Games gold medalists [[Andrew Lloyd (athlete)|Andrew Lloyd]] and [[Kate Anderson-Richardson|Kate Anderson]], as well as [[Carolyn Schuwalow]], [[Susan Hobson]], [[Benita Willis]], [[Sisay Bezabeh]], [[Martin Dent]], [[Nicky Carroll]], [[Mizan Mehari]] and [[Lisa Corrigan]].<ref name=lenton/><ref name=rfyl>{{cite journal|last=Wiasak|first=Rebecca|title=Dick Telford : running in the shadows|journal=Run For Your Life|issue=Dec–Jan 2007-2008|pages=14–17|issn=1832-7079}}</ref> At the [[Australia at the 2012 Summer Olympics|2012 London Olympics]] two of his athletes [[Lisa Weightman]] and [[Michael Shelley (athlete)|Michael Shelley]] were selected. Both athletes won medals at the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]]. He coached Shelley to win the [[2014 Commonwealth Games]] Men's Marathon gold medal.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Page|first1=Fleta|title=Dick Telford: the master coach behind Michael Shelley's marathon success|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/act-sport/dick-telford-the-master-coach-behind-michael-shelleys-marathon-success-20140801-zzff5.html|accessdate=7 October 2014|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=1 August 2014}}</ref>
He was distance running coach on the Australian teams at the [[Australia at the 1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Barcelona]] and [[Australia at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996 Atlanta Olympics]].<ref name=olympic>{{cite book|title=The Compendium : Official Australian Olympic statistics 1896-2002|year=2003|publisher=University of Queensland Press|location=Brisbane}}</ref>
==Recognition== *1988 - Foundation Fellow of [[Sports Medicine Australia]] *1990 - Fellow of [[American College of Sports Medicine]] *1992 - Member of the Order of Australia for service to sport and sport science.<ref name=honour/> *2008 - State Finalist (ACT) Senior [[Australian of the Year]] *2014 - [[Sport Australia Hall of Fame]] General Member<ref name=sahof>{{cite web|title=Dick Telford|url=http://www.sahof.org.au/hall-of-fame/member-profile/?memberID=575&memberType=general|website=Sport Australia Hall of Fame website|accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref> *2014 - [[Athletics Australia]] Australian Sports Commission Coach of the Year<ref>{{cite web|title=Athlete of the Year|url=http://www.athletics.com.au/News/ArtMID/7243/ArticleID/1106565/ATHLETE-OF-THE-YEAR|website=Athletics Australia News, 23 October 2014|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref> *2017 - ACT Senior [[Australian of the Year]]<ref>{{cite news|title=ACT Senior Australian of the Year Dick Telford|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-31/act-senior-australian-of-the-year-dick-telford/7981852|accessdate=31 October 2016|work=ABC News|date=31 October 2016}}</ref> *2018 - ACT Sport Hall of Fame Associate Member <ref>{{cite news |title=Dick Telford was a star cricket coach before running |url=https://www.canberratimes.com.au/topic/act-sport-5u2/dick-telford-was-a-star-cricket-coach-before-running-20181106-p50ebf.html |accessdate=18 November 2018 |work=Canberra Times |date=10 November 2018}}</ref>
==Bibliography== *[http://trove.nla.gov.au/version/214837568 Running : through the looking glass / Dick Telford, Griffith, A.C.T. Barrallier Books Pty Ltd, 2015] * [http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/6563581 Take care of yourself : your personal guide to self-care and preventing illness, Richard D. Telford .. {et.al.}, Sydney : Addison-Wesley, 1993]

{{Infobox museum | name = Museo y Circuito Fernando Alonso | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | alt = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|43.42768|N|5.82862|W|display=inline}} | established = 2011 | dissolved = | location = [[Llanera, Asturias]], [[Spain]] | type = [[Transport museum]] | collection = Over 270 items<ref name="official-museum" /> | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = http://www.fernandoalonso.com/en/museum/ }} The '''Fernando Alonso Sports Complex''' ({{lang-es|Complejo Deportivo Fernando Alonso}}, also known as {{lang-es|Museo y Circuit Fernando Alonso}}) is a sports project dedicated to the promotion of motorsport and a memorial to [[Fernando Alonso]], a two-times Formula One World Drivers' Champion from [[Oviedo]], [[Asturias]], [[Spain]]. The facility is located in [[Llanera, Asturias]].
== Facilities == The complex includes a museum about Fernando Alonso, a [[kart circuit]], and a [[golf course]].
=== Museum === The complex's Fernando Alonso Collection includes most of racing cars which Alonso has competed in since his age of 3, racing suits and helmets which he worn, and the trophies which he acquired.<ref name="official-museum" /> Apart from those originating from Alonso himself, his helmet collection of other professional drivers is on exhibition.<ref name="SoyMotor-180116" />
; Notable collection * All [[Formula One car]]s which Alonso raced before {{f1|2016}} including the championship winning [[Renault R25]] and [[Renault R26|R26]] * Renault RS25 engine from the [[2005 FIA Formula One World Championship|2005 Formula One season]] * 2017 McLaren-Honda-Andretti Dallara DW12. Which Alonso drove in the [[2017 Indianapolis 500]].
=== Kart circuit === The karting circuit is spread over 44,446.54 m² and was designed and built with the possibility of making twenty-nine different tracks, whose lengths vary between 1,400 and 1,800 meters.<ref name="official-kartcircuit" /> The main circuit can be divided into three secondary courses of 721, 637 and 372 meters to facilitate training.<ref name="official-kartcircuit" /> It is approved to host international competitions at the highest level according to CIK-FIA standards.<ref name="CIK-FIA-Presentation2017" />
The circuit was premiered by Fernando Alonso himself on March 18, 2011 in front of 4,000 people.
== References == {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="official-kartcircuit">{{cite web|title= Karting Circuit|url=http://www.fernandoalonso.com/en/karting-circuit/ |publisher=Fernando Alonso official website |language=English|accessdate=2018-02-06}}</ref> <ref name="official-museum">{{cite web|title= Fernando Alonso Collection|url=http://www.fernandoalonso.com/en/museum/ |publisher=Fernando Alonso official website |language=English|accessdate=2018-02-06}}</ref> <ref name="CIK-FIA-Presentation2017">{{cite web|title= FIRST CIK-FIA COMPETITIONS AT THE ALONSO CIRCUIT |url=http://www.cikfia.com/fileadmin/content/Camps/Media/2017/Alonso/Alonso_Preview.pdf |publisher=CIK-FIA |language=English|date=2017|accessdate=2018-02-06}}</ref> <ref name="SoyMotor-180116">{{cite web|title= El casco de Vandoorne 2017 ya luce en el museo de Alonso |url=http://soymotor.com/noticias/el-casco-de-vandoorne-2017-ya-luce-en-el-museo-de-alonso-942865 |publisher=SoyMotor |language=Spanish|date=2018-01-16|accessdate=2018-02-06}}</ref>
}}
== External links == * [http://www.fernandoalonso.com/en/ Fernando Alonso official website]

revision.text:
[[File:Grady Sizemore Foam Finger.jpg|thumb|right|A fan raises a foam hand at a [[Cleveland Indians]] game.]] A '''foam hand''', also known as a '''foam finger''', is a sports paraphernalia item worn on the hand to show support for a particular team. The most common version resembles an oversized hand with an extended index finger, and slits in their bases allow them to be worn over the hands. Usually the surface displays a [[silk-screen]]ed team name, [[logo]], or other graphic or slogan, such as "We Are #1." Foam hands are made of open-celled foam.
==History== [[File:1971 FoamFinger.jpg|thumb|right|Steve Chmelar showing his original fan spirit. (1971)]][[File:1971 finger2.JPG|thumb|right|Recent (2012) photo of the 1971 item, signed by members of the Ottumwa High School Class of 1971.]] The first prototype foam finger was created in 1971 by [[Ottumwa High School]] student Steve Chmelar, who constructed a giant hand out of hardware cloth and papier-mâché for the 1971 [[Iowa High School Athletic Association]] Boy's State Basketball Finals, between the Ottumwa Bulldogs and the Davenport West Falcons. A senior in high school, Steve's photo was taken by the Associated Press and published in the [[Des Moines Tribune]] and the 1971 Ottumwa High School class yearbook, the ''Argus'', in Ottumwa, Iowa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/09/13/inventor-wags-his-oversized-finger-at-miley-cyrus/2812835/|title=Inventor wags his oversized finger at Miley Cyrus|last=Kilen|first=Mike|date=2013-09-13|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2017-10-08|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
In 1976, Texas high school teacher Geral Fauss created foam fingers to show support for the team at the high school where he taught, to raise funds for the industrial arts club, and as a project that his industrial arts class could produce themselves. His first prototype foam finger was actually made out of plywood and had a painting of a "number one" done in the school's colors.
Fauss first sold his foam fingers at the [[1978 Cotton Bowl Classic|1978 Cotton Bowl]] in Dallas ([[Texas Longhorns football|University of Texas]] vs. [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]])<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2013/08/creator-foam-finger-deeply-upset-miley-cyrus/311615/|title=Creator of the Foam Finger Is Deeply Upset with Miley Cyrus|last=Abad-Santos|first=Alexander|date=2013-08-29|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-10-08|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>, and he later went on to found Spirit Industries for the large scale manufacturing of foam fingers. In 1979, the first polyurethane foam version of the product was produced by Spirit Industries.
==Common shape variations== *Instead of a human hand, the foam finger is in the shape of a talon, hoof, paw, or other hand-analog to resemble that of the team mascot. *The index finger, thumb, and pinky are extended in the [[American Sign Language]] sign for ''love''. Often this version is captioned, "Gotta Love Those [team name]." *The index finger and pinky are extended to represent gestures such as [[University of South Florida]]'s "Go Bulls" or [[University of Texas]]' "[[Hook 'em Horns]]." *The middle finger is extended in the obscene [[hand gesture]] [[the finger]].
Besides being sold at all manner of sporting events and venues as souvenirs, foam fingers are used as fund-raisers for schools and booster clubs as well as corporate promotions.
To date, the majority of "foam hands" have been produced in a [[plane (geometry)|planar]]-like form. However, in early 2009, a product that more-closely replicates the dimensional form of a human hand (like [[Hulk Hands]] with an extended finger) was introduced and marketed under the [[trade name]] [[Radhand]] until 2010 when it was renamed UltimateHand, produced by a new company called BrettHand.
== See also == *[[Foam tomahawk]]
==External links== {{commons category-inline|Foam hands}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Foam Hand}} [[Category:Sports paraphernalia]]

{{Infobox museum |name = Galatasaray Museum | native_name = Galatasaray Müzesi |image = Galatasaray Museum.JPG |imagesize = 250 |established = 1868 |coordinates = {{coord|41.03376|28.97749|display=inline}} |collection = |location = Galatasaray Square, Beyoğlu, [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] |type = Culture&[[Art museum]] |visitors = |director = Münevver Eminoğlu |website = [http://www.galatasaray.org/tarih/pages/tarih_muze.php Galatasaray Website] }} '''Galatasaray Museum''' (officially Galatasaray University Culture&Art Center) ({{lang-tr|Galatasaray Müzesi}}) is a cultural center in Istanbul, Turkey, founded in 1868 by [[Ali Sami Yen]], to inform the society of the traditions and history of Galatasaray. The museum is open to the public everyday except Mondays. ==The Building== The museum initially opened at Kalamış Bay. Later in 1919, it was moved to [[Galatasaray High School]]. The museum building, formerly known as Galatasaray Post Office, was restored and remodelled to suit a museum. Galatasaray Museum was renovated and reopened in 2009 with a very successful and contemporary exhibition concept. ==Admission and location== ;Museum hours *Tuesday - Sunday: 10.00 - 19.00 *Closed on Mondays. ;Admission: *Free admission for all. ;Address İstiklal Caddesi No: 90
Beyoğlu - İstanbul, Turkey ===First Floor - Lycee de Galatasaray & Galatasaray University Section=== File:GS Lisesi - GS Museum 1.JPG|Galatasaray Museum Lycee de Galatasaray File:GS Lisesi - GS Museum 2.JPG|Galatasaray Museum Lycee de Galatasaray File:Galatasaray Era.JPG|1481-1826 Galata Sarayı Enderun Mektebi Era File:Galatasaray Era 2.JPG|1838-1868 Galata Sarayı Mekteb-i Tıbbiye-i Şahane Era File:Galatasaray Era 3.JPG|1874-1881 Era of Mekteb-i Sultani File:Galatasaray Era 4.JPG|1874-1881 Darülfünun-ı Sultani Era File:Galatasaray Era 5.JPG|
1868-1923 Second Constitutional Era
 First floor of this museum is dedicated to Lycee de Galatasaray and Galatasaray University. ===Second Floor - Galatasaray Sports Club Section=== File:Galatasaray Müzesi Tavan.JPG|Galatasaray Museum Ceiling File:Galatasaray Müzesi Kapı.JPG|

The club competes in the second basketball division in [[Belgium]]. The team was founded in 1950. The team plays home games at the 2,374 seat Tolhuis. The club has played in the Belgian highest division since 2007. The season before, they became champion in the second division. == Names == {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| * 1950 – 1991 : Hellas Gent * 1991 – 1995 : Bobcat Gent * 1995 – 1997 : AST Gent * 1997 – 2000 : Siemens Gent * 2000 – 2002 : Gent United * 2002 – 2007 : Gent Dragons * 2007 – 2012 : Optima Gent * 2012 – 2013: Gent Dragons * 2013 – present: Gent Hawks }} ==Season by season== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%" |- bgcolor= !Season ! [[Image:Ice racing.jpg|right|thumb|[[Volkswagen Beetle]] racing on ice]]
'''Ice racing''' is a form of racing that uses [[automobile|cars]], [[motorcycle]]s, [[snowmobile]]s, [[all-terrain vehicle]]s, or other motorized vehicles. Ice racing takes place on [[freezing|frozen]] [[lake]]s or [[river]]s, or on groomed frozen lots. As cold weather is a requirement for natural [[ice]], it is usually found at higher latitudes in [[Canada]], the northern [[United States]], and in northern [[Europe]], although limited indoor events are held in warmer climates, typically on ice hockey rinks (motorcycles and ATVs only).<ref>{{cite web|author=vbo designs vbo@vbodesigns.com vbodesigns.com |url=http://www.icespeedway.com/ |title=International Championship Events |publisher=Icespeedway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-08}}</ref> Tracks in North America vary from 1/4 mile (~400 m) long ovals<ref>[http://www.dirtrider.com/features/ww/141_0603_canada_ice_race/ "Weekend Warrior: Motorcycle Ice Racing - The Boys of Winter"] Mitch Brown; [[Dirt Rider]] magazine; Retrieved February 1, 2007</ref> to several mile-long road course designs.
In Sweden and Finland ice racing have been big event since 1960 about.
==Track== Tracks used for ice racing include ovals and [[road courses]].<ref name="MotorTrend" /> Some tracks are [[dirt track racing]] tracks with the snow plowed off them. When there is no natural snow, an icy surface may be created by spraying the dirt surface with water when the temperature is below freezing. Artificial ice tracks (usually [[speed skating]] ovals) are used where it is not possible to construct natural ice tracks. Some tracks are made by plowing the snow off an area of a frozen lake. Spectators frequently park their cars around the outside of the track on a frozen lake.<ref name=fastrax>{{citation |author=Scott Owens |title=Ice Racing is HOT on Lake Speed |publisher=Fastrax Monthly |date=April 2007 }}</ref>
In the [[UK]] ice meetings have been staged at ice rinks. The longest running event, at [[Telford]], features riders using conventional machines with spiked tires. In the late 1960s ice racing was staged at a number of rinks in Scotland but the machines used were rally based machines with all season tires.
In Nordic countries track are about one mile. Many tracks are very different
==Tires== [[Image:Spikes-Rennmotorrad.jpg|thumb|upright|Close-up of a studded tire]] Ice racing [[tire]]s are either [[screw|studded]] or non-studded.<ref name="MotorTrend" /> Studded tires have a stud such as a [[screw]] or bolt to provide better traction and increased speed.<ref name=fastrax /> Some studs are sharpened to increase penetration.<ref name=fastrax /> Tires cannot be purchased with studs, so the pit crew needs to attach the studs to the tire.<ref name=fastrax /> Through 2008, [[Team Menard|Menard's Racing]] in Wisconsin manufactured and sold studded racing tires for cars, and they were required in many ice-racing classes. Cars with studded tires are generally required to contain a [[roll cage]] and increased safety equipment since they achieve much more speed with the greater cornering abilities.<ref name="MotorTrend" />
The sanctioning body's rule book generally specifies the length and/or type of stud, often with the goal of controlling the level of damage done to the ice surface. Aggressive studs can cause enough damage to be a safety concern as they wear through the ice on successive laps, particularly during door-to-door auto racing.
Non-studded tires are standard production snow tires, as used on highway-use passenger cars in colder climates. Drivers often use [[winter tires]].<ref name="MotorTrend" /> Favorites among ice-racers include the Bridgestone Blizzaks and Nokian Hakkapeliittas.
Nordic we have tree different tires one are same than Sweden rally tires then step bigger are 11mm long spikes and Swedish have class for 23mm spike+8mm nut so they are long ones
==Motorcycle ice racing==<!-- This section is linked from [[Motorcycle speedway]] --> {{Main article|Ice speedway}} [[Image:Motorcycly speedway on ice.jpg|thumb|left|Motorcycle ice road racing]] [[Image:Ice Racing.jpg|thumb|left|Motorcycle ice racing using studded tires]] Ice racing includes a [[Ice speedway|motorcycle class]] which is the equivalent of [[motorcycle speedway|Speedway]] on ice. Bikes race [[anti-clockwise]] around oval tracks between {{convert|260|m|mi|abbr=on}} and {{convert|425|m|mi|abbr=on}} in length. The race structure and scoring is similar to Speedway.
The bikes bear a passing resemblance to those used for speedway, but have a longer [[wheelbase]] and a more rigid frame. The sport is divided into classes for full-[[rubber]] and [[screw|studded]] [[tire]]s. The studded tire category involves competitors riding on bikes with spikes up to {{convert|30|mm|in}} in length screwed into each tread-less tyre, each bike has 90 spikes on the front tyre and 200–500 on the rear. The use of these spikes in this discipline necessitate the addition of special protective guards (similar to [[mudguard]]s) over the wheels which extend almost to the ice surface. The spiked tyres produce a tremendous amount of [[Traction (engineering)|traction]] and this means two-speed gearboxes are also required. As with speedway, the bikes do not have brakes. Czech made [[4-stroke]] [[Jawa Motors|Jawa]] motorcycles have been the dominant force in this sport.
In the studded tyre class there is no broadsiding around the bends due to the grip produced by the spikes digging into the ice. Instead, riders lean their bikes into the bends at an angle where the handlebars just skim the track surface. Speeds approach {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on the straights, and {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on the bends. The safety barrier usually consists of straw bales or banked-up snow and ice around the outer edge of the track.
The riding style required for studded ice racing is different from that used in the other [[track racing]] disciplines. This means riders from this discipline rarely participate in Speedway or its other variants and vice versa.
The majority of [[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme]] sanctioned team and individual meetings are held in [[Russia]], [[Sweden]] and [[Finland]], but events are also held in the [[Czech Republic]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]] (since 2000), the [[Netherlands]], and occasionally other countries. Countries that dominated and won the majority of titles in [[Individual Ice Racing World Championship]] (held since 1966) and [[Team Ice Racing World Championship]] (held since 1979) were the [[USSR]] and since 1991—[[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.speedway-faq.org/wchamps.html |title=World Champions |publisher=Speedway FAQ |date= |accessdate=2011-08-08}}</ref> [[Canada]]'s national touring series is sanctioned by the [[Canadian Motorcycle Association]].
==Automobile ice racing== [[File:EmbarrassRiverIceRacingTilledaThunderRWDStudded.jpg|thumb|float|Studded tires on autos causing limited visibility]] [[File:Motortävlingpåisen12219872344.jpg|thumb|Automobile ice racing in the late 19th century.]] Automobile ice races have been most successful in [[France]], where the [[Trophée Andros]] series, sponsored by an industrial [[jam]] manufacturer attracts ex-F1 drivers like [[Alain Prost]] or [[Olivier Panis]], manufacturer-backed entries of sophisticated [[Four-wheel drive|4WD]] cars and international [[television]] coverage. The Trophée Andros races mainly use damped snow (that is not very different from ice regarding car handling) tracks in French ski resorts with a final race on artificial ice in Paris [[Stade de France]]. The 2006 trophy includes one round in [[Andorra]]. On several occasions a round also took place in [[Canada]], in the Canadian Challenge, which is held yearly and is the most notable Ice Racing event in North America.
In the 1960s and 1970s, there were two major Ice Racing Championships, the [[North American Ice Racing Championship]] and the [[European Ice Racing Championship]]. The North American was held in [[Anchorage, Alaska]] and their champions include [[Earl Bennett (racing driver)|Earl Bennett]] and [[Chuck Higgins (racing driver)|Chuck Higgins]], while Mexican [[Formula One]] driver [[Pedro Rodríguez (racing driver)|Pedro Rodríguez]] won his class and an exhibition race in 1970, and was 2nd overall.
Elsewhere, ice racing has proven to be a largely [[recreation]]al pastime. There is no professional ice-racing sanctioning body in North America,<ref name="MotorTrend" /> but there are clubs in several Canadian provinces (Alberta, Ontario, Manitoba, Quebec, Saskatchewan) and American states (New York, Michigan, Maine, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Alaska<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aksportscarclub.org |title=Anchorage Alaska Sports Car Lions Club |publisher=aksportscarclub.org |date= |accessdate=2013-01-06}}</ref>). Some amateur and professional [[dirt track racing|dirt track]] and paved track racers use ice racing to hone their skills or to practice for the summer season.<ref name="MotorTrend" /><ref name=fastrax /> Drivers often find that developing the car control skills needed on ice substantially improves their performance on a wet race track.
There is a new class in Canada called SS (street studs) where a car can run with the same modifications as a rubber to ice class, without the need for a roll bar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casc.on.ca |title=CASC Ontario - Home |publisher=Casc.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-08-08}}</ref> This same SS classing, although referred to as Super Stud or Studded class, by some American Clubs (such as the Anchorage Alaska Sports Car Lions Club) require any car running studded tires to meet at least IT rules and requires a roll cage and full safety gear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aksportscarclub.org/bylaws-rules/comp-rules.html |title=Anchorage Alaska Sports Car Lions Club |publisher=aksportscarclub.org |date= |accessdate=2013-01-06}}</ref> Some clubs even encourage people to ice-race their daily driver, and have strict no-contact rules to allow that safely.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icerace.com/GSIIR.htm |title=AMEC Getting Started |publisher=Icerace.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-08}}</ref>
In [[Russia]] there is a [[rally raid]] event, called the [[Northern Forest]] run on ice and snow in the last days of February in the outskirts of the city of [[St Petersburg]]. Also, in Russia exist popular winter track racing, where pilots race on short ice oval track, usually hippodroms, covered with ice during winter.<ref>[http://rutube.ru/tracks/3233417.html Film about russian winter track racing]</ref>
Conventional [[rallying]] also takes place on ice. Most notably, the tarmac of the [[Monte Carlo Rally]] is occasionally covered with snow and ice. The [[Sno Drift Rally]] in Michigan is another example of such events.
===Race vehicle=== There are many classes of racing vehicles. The racing vehicles are frequently divided into studded or non-studded tire classes. Nearly all [[Dirt track racing#The race vehicle|dirt track racing]] vehicles could be raced on ice. Flying snow and ice powder limits visibility, so some vehicles are required to have a bright light, normally red or yellow, on the back of the car for greater visibility in the powder.<ref name="MotorTrend" /><ref name=fastrax />
Non-studded cars are selected by their weight since non-studded cars cannot carry high speed through a corner and cars cannot get much power to the slippery surface.<ref name="MotorTrend" /> Lightweight front-wheel drive cars are generally the quickest.<ref name="MotorTrend" />
==Ice racing in film== Ice racing was featured in the 1969 [[James Bond]] film ''[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service (film)|On Her Majesty's Secret Service]]'' with [[George Lazenby]] and [[Diana Rigg]] as they attempted to evade their pursuers. The track was in [[Switzerland]].<ref name="MotorTrend">{{cite web|url=http://www.motortrend.com/features/112_0407_ice_racing/index.html|title=Racing Fast 'n' Cheap: Ice Racing|last=Markus|first=Frank|publisher=[[Motor Trend]]|accessdate=2008-09-30}}</ref>
Motorcycle ice racing footage can be seen in the [[Bruce Brown]] documentary ''[[On Any Sunday]]''.
==Media== {{Listen|filename=IceRacingShawanoLakeWisconsinFireOnIce.ogg|title=Ice racing|description=Ice racing stock cars in [[Wisconsin]], USA — 2.3 MB|format=[[Ogg]]}}
==See also== * [[Icetrack cycling]] * [[Ice yachting]]

'''Ira Gitler''' (born December 18, 1928, [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]) is an American [[jazz]] historian and journalist.<ref>Answers.com website. [http://www.answers.com/topic/ira-gitler Ira Gitler.] Retrieved Oct. 16, 2008.</ref> The co-author of ''The Biographical Encyclopedia of Jazz'' with [[Leonard Feather]]—the most recent edition appeared in 1999—he has written hundreds of liner notes for jazz recordings since the early 1950s and is the author of dozens of books about jazz and [[ice hockey]], two of his passions.<ref name="manhattan">Manhattan School of Music. [http://www.msmnyc.edu/catalog/facbio.asp?fid=1008172953 Faculty: Mr. Ira Gitler.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070209043429/http://www.msmnyc.edu/catalog/facbio.asp?fid=1008172953 |date=2007-02-09 }} Retrieved Oct. 16, 2008.</ref>
==Jazz== Gitler was born in a Jewish family and grew up listening to [[swing music|swing]] bands in the late 1930s and 1940s, before discovering the new music of [[Charlie Parker]] and [[Dizzy Gillespie]]. In the early 1950s, he worked as a producer for many recording sessions of [[Prestige Records]]. He is credited with coining the term "[[sheets of sound]]" in the late 1950s, to describe the playing of [[John Coltrane]].<ref>All About Jazz website. [http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/news.php?id=11572 John Coltrane "Sheets of Sound" Summit at New York City's Manhattan School of Music.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070123221251/http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/news.php?id=11572 |date=2007-01-23 }} Nov. 6, 2006. Retrieved Oct. 16, 2008.</ref>
==Editor== Gitler was the New York editor of ''[[Down Beat]]'' magazine during the 1960s and has written for ''[[Metronome Magazine]]'', ''[[JazzTimes]]'', ''Jazz Improv'', ''[[Modern Drummer]]'', the ''[[New York Times]]'', the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', the ''[[Village Voice]]'', ''[[VIBE|Vibe]]'', ''[[Playboy]]'', ''World Monitor'', and ''[[New York Magazine]]''. Internationally he has contributed to the magazines ''Swing Journal'' (Japan), ''Musica Jazz'' (Italy) and ''Jazz Magazine'' (France). He was awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] in 1974.<ref name="manhattan"/>
Gitler was given Lifetime Achievement Awards by the [[New Jersey Jazz Society]] (in 2001) and by the [[Jazz Journalists Association]] (in 2002).<ref name="manhattan"/>
In 2017 Gitler was awarded an NEA Jazz Masters Fellowship.<ref>https://www.arts.gov/honors/jazz/ira-gitler</ref>
Gitler's passion for ice hockey has prompted him to write several books on the subject.<ref>Amazon.com. [https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_ss_gw?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=ira+gitler+ice+hockey&x=9&y=17 Ira Gitler.] Retrieved Oct. 16, 2008.</ref> He also wrote for the [[New York Rangers]] as well as the [[National Hockey League]] in their former magazine, ''Goal.''
==Books== * ''Jazz Masters of the Forties''; New York: Macmillan, 1966. * ''Make the Team in Ice Hockey''; New York: Macmillan, 1968. * ''Hockey! The Story of the World's Fastest Sport'', with Richard Beddoes and Stan Fischler; New York: Macmillan, 1969. * ''Blood on the Ice: Hockey's Most Violent Moments''; Chicago: H. Regnery Co., 1974. * ''The Encyclopedia of Jazz in the Seventies'', with [[Leonard Feather]]; New York: Horizon Press, 1976. {{ISBN|0-8180-1215-3}}. * ''Ice Hockey A to Z''; New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard, 1978. {{ISBN|0-688-41842-2}}. * ''Swing to Bop: An Oral History of the Transition in Jazz in the 1940s''; New York: Oxford University Press, 1985. {{ISBN|0-19-503664-6}}. * ''The Biographical Encyclopedia of Jazz'', with Leonard Feather and the assistance of ''Swing'' journal (Tokyo); New York: Oxford University Press, 1999. {{ISBN|0-19-507418-1}}. * ''The Masters of Bebop: A Listener's Guide''; New York: Da Capo Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-306-81009-3}}.

(renovations 1987–present) | structural engineer = LHC Structural Engineers (renovations 1979–present) | general_contractor = TC Thompson & Co. | former_names = | tenants = [[North Carolina Tar Heels]] ([[NCAA]]) (1927–present) | seating_capacity = 24,000 (1927–1962, expandable to 40,000)

50,500 (2018) | dimensions = 360 x 160 ft }} '''Kenan Memorial Stadium''' is located in [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina]] and is the home field of the [[North Carolina Tar Heels]]. It is primarily used for [[American football|football]]. The stadium opened in 1927 and holds 50,500 people. It is located near the center of campus at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|University of North Carolina]]. ==History== The previous home of the Tar Heels had been Emerson Field, which had opened in 1916 on the current site of Davis Library. By 1925, it was obvious that that 2,400-seat facility was not adequate for the increasing crowds. Expansion was quickly ruled out since the baseball team also used it, and any new football seats would have been too far away for baseball. Funding for the stadium was originally supposed to come from alumni donations. [[William R. Kenan, Jr.]], a dairy farmer from [[Lockport (city), New York|Lockport, New York]] who would later become a prominent businessman in [[Miami]],{{cite web|title=Southern Beauty|first=David E.|last=Brown|url=http://alumni.unc.edu/article.aspx?sid=572|publisher=UNC General Alumni Association|date=September 2002|accessdate=November 6, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131106051434/http://alumni.unc.edu/article.aspx?sid=572|archivedate=November 6, 2013|df=}} got word of the initial plans and donated a large gift to build the stadium and an adjoining field house. Kenan was an 1894 UNC graduate and grandson of one of UNC's original trustees. Kenan persuaded UNC to build the stadium as a memorial to his parents, William R. Kenan and Mary Hargrave Kenan. Ground was broken in November 1926. It was completed in August 1927. At the time, it was located on the far southern portion of campus, but expansions over the years have resulted in the stadium now being near the center of campus. The stadium officially opened on November 24, 1927. The Tar Heels defeated [[Davidson College]] 27-0, with the first touchdown in the new stadium by [[Edison Foard]]. The first game at Kenan Stadium brought in 9,000 spectators. It was officially dedicated to the Kenan family on Thanksgiving Day in 1927 in front of 28,000 fans, after the Tar Heels beat the [[Virginia Cavaliers football|Virginia Cavaliers]] 14-13. The original stadium - the lower level of the current stadium's sideline seats - seated 24,000 people. However, temporary bleachers were added to the end zones to accommodate overflow crowds, allowing Kenan to accommodate over 40,000 people at times. This happened fairly often over the years, especially during the [[Charlie Justice (American football player)|Choo Choo Justice]] era of the late 1940s. ===Expansions=== [[Image:Kenan1.jpg|300px|right|thumb|The West End Zone addition in 1998 created a [[horseshoe]].]] The stadium was first expanded in 1963, when Kenan (who died in 1965) donated $1 million to double-deck the sideline seats and add permanent bleachers to the end zones, expanding capacity to 48,000. A seating adjustment in 1979 boosted capacity to 50,000. In 1988, the old press box and chancellor's box were replaced by 2,000 seats between the 40-yard lines, expanding capacity to 52,000. The stadium's biggest renovation project to date took place from 1995 to 1998. Head coach [[Mack Brown]] wanted a better facility to showcase a resurgent football program, which had gone from consecutive 1-10 seasons in 1988 and 1989 to a run of success not approached since the 1940s. For instance, Kenan was one of the few Division I stadiums not to have permanent seating in at least one end zone; the only end zone seats at the time were the portable bleachers added in 1963. Also, the locker rooms were somewhat cramped by 1990s standards. Several generous gifts resulted in the addition of a new playing field and a brand-new facility for the football team, the Frank H. Kenan Football Center, named for the great-grandson of the stadium's original benefactor. The Kenan Center included a memorabilia section showcasing the football program's history. The most visible addition, however, was 8,000 new seats in the west end zone, which turned the stadium into a [[horseshoe]]. Also added was a "preferred seating box" atop the north stands. Due to state law, only 6,000 of the new end zone seats were available in 1997. Capacity dropped to 48,500 in 1996, but leaped to 57,800 in 1997. The other 2,200 seats were added in 1998, bringing the stadium to a capacity of 60,000, not eclipsed until the 2011 season. In 2003, a modern scoreboard with video capability was added in front of Kenan Field House. The next addition came before the 2007 season, when the old matrix boards on the sidelines were replaced with ribbon boards. The 2011 renovation and expansion fully enclosed the stadium for the first time in its history. This facility houses the Loudermilk Center for Student Excellence as well as 3,000 additional premium club, suite seating and lounge areas in the east end zone, bringing total stadium capacity to 63,000. As part of this addition, high-definition video boards were installed on each end of the stadium. In 2016, new ribbon boards and updated concessions were added.{{cite web|url=http://www.goheels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=3350&ATCLID=211147792|title=Exciting Upgrades At Kenan This Fall - University of North Carolina|author=|date=|website=University of North Carolina|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024160707/http://www.goheels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=3350&ATCLID=211147792|archivedate=2016-10-24|df=}} In 2018, the change from bleachers to individual seating reduced capacity to 51,000.https://goheels.com/news/2018/1/7/football-individual-seats-coming-in-kenan-stadium.aspx ==2011 expansion timeline== In December 2006, the Chapel Hill Town Council approved changes to UNC's development plan that included at least 8,800 additional seats for Kenan Stadium.{{cite news |title=Plan to Expand Kenan Excites UNC's Davis|first=Robbi|last=Pickeral|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/122/story/647326.html|newspaper=[[The News & Observer]]|location=Raleigh|date=July 24, 2007|accessdate=July 24, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016132503/http://www.newsobserver.com/122/story/647326.html|archivedate=October 16, 2008}} [[File:McCorkle Center.JPG|thumb|The Loudermilk Center in the east end zone, which turned the stadium into a bowl. Includes the Blue Zone.]] In October 2007, athletic director [[Dick Baddour]] announced plans for extensive renovations to Kenan Stadium. Plans call for a new academic support center in place of Kenan Field House, plus anywhere from 5,000 to 15,000 additional seats. The new seats will be added in the east end zone, turning the stadium into a bowl. Plans would have to be approved by the chancellor and the board of trustees, and will almost certainly require a fundraising effort by the Rams Club. No specific timetable had been set, but Baddour had said that he hoped to begin construction within 18 months.{{cite news |title=Kenan Expansion Planning 'On Target'|first=Robbi|last=Pickeral|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/734/story/730550.html|newspaper=[[The News & Observer]]|location=Raleigh|date=October 9, 2007|accessdate=October 9, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016132643/http://www.newsobserver.com/734/story/730550.html|archivedate=October 16, 2008}} This "masterplan" would be divided into two phases; phase one covering the west end zone and two covering the east end zone. The first phase consisted of adding a fifth floor (for recruiting and media space) along with remodeling the existing offices and team spaces in the Kenan Football Center. Approved on July 23, 2008, by the Board of Trustees for $50 million, Phase I renovations were completed on August for the 2009 Football Season.{{cite news|title=Economic Woes Halt Addition to Kenan Stadium |first=Robbi |last=Pickeral |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/sports/college/unc/football/story/1432297.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140905144730/http://www.newsobserver.com/sports/college/unc/football/story/1432297.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 5, 2014 |newspaper=[[The News & Observer]] |location=Raleigh |date=July 23, 2008 |accessdate=July 23, 2008 }} A third and final phase of the project was also planned. This will include new club-level seats around the perimeter of the stadium, a new suite level above the club seats, a much larger press box, and a brick facade encircling the outside of the stadium. Construction of this phase has not been scheduled, however, due to budgetary constraints. ===Phase II and the Blue Zone=== On May 27, 2010, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Board of Trustees approved the immediate commencement on construction of the "Carolina Student-Athlete Center for Excellence", a $70 million expansion that would replace Kenan Field House, which was built in 1927. The entire project was funded by private donations and the selling of club seats and individual suites. This facility would be a combination of an academic center, "Carolina Leadership Academy", Olympic sports' strength and conditioning center, and visitor lockers within a span of two floors.{{cite web|title=Kenan Ready for Phase I Expansion|url=http://unc5corners.blogspot.com/2008/07/kenan-stadium-ready-for-phase-one-of.html|publisher=Fifth Corner|date=July 28, 2008|accessdate=October 3, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214135009/http://unc5corners.blogspot.com/2008/07/kenan-stadium-ready-for-phase-one-of.html|archivedate=December 14, 2008|df=}}{{cite news |title=Kenan Expands|first=Samuel|last=Spies|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/sports/story/1151325.html|newspaper=[[The News & Observer]]|location=Raleigh|date=|accessdate=July 23, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080804212020/http://www.newsobserver.com/sports/story/1151325.html|archivedate=August 4, 2008}} However, the most significantly visible portion of the renovation was the addition of 2,980 seats, turning the stadium into a bowl. The additional seats in the end zone, named the Blue Zone, would be "1,836 seats in the Concourse Club just a few feet from the field, 824 seats in the Upper Club/Loge on the fourth floor and 320 seats in 20 suites on the fifth floor". The individual suites, each of which has 16 seats, will sell for $50,000 per year. Each seat in the club levels range from $750 to $2,500 per season.{{cite web|title=Board of Trustees Approve Carolina's Student-Athlete Center For Excellence|url=http://www.goheels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=667864&SPID=12962&DB_LANG=C&SITE=UNC&DB_OEM_ID=3350&ATCLID=205496014|publisher=University of North Carolina Athletic Department|date=May 27, 2010|accessdate=May 27, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503142316/http://www.goheels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=667864&SPID=12962&DB_LANG=C&SITE=UNC&DB_OEM_ID=3350&ATCLID=205496014|archivedate=May 3, 2015|df=}} Furthermore, the construction of a new concourse in front of the Carolina Student-Athlete Center for Excellence would allow fans to move around the entire perimeter of Kenan Stadium for the first time. The exterior of the new section is similar in appearance to the Bell Tower. == 2018 change in dedication == William R. Kenan, to whom the stadium was dedicated, "was the commander of a white supremacist paramilitary force, which massacred scores of black residents in Wilmington, on a single day in 1898."{{cite news |title=UNC will remove plaques at Kenan Stadium honoring Kenan family member who had ties to Wilmington massacr| |newspaper=WRALsportsfan ([[WRAL-TV]]) |date=October 3, 2018 |url=https://www.wralsportsfan.com/unc-will-remove-plaques-at-kenan-stadium-honoring-kenan-family-member-who-had-ties-to-wilmington-massacre/17891899/ |accessdate=October 12, 2018}}{{cite news |title=Kenan Memorial Stadium: racism and white supremacy are hidden beyond a dedication plaque |date=September 28, 2018 |first=Hannah |last=McClellan |newspaper=[[Daily Tar Heel]] |url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2018/09/kenan-stadium-wilmington-massacre-0927}}{{cite web |title=UNC's Football Stadium: Memorial to the Leader of a White Supremacist Massacre |date=September 19, 2018 |first=Craig |last=Calcaterra |url=https://www.craigcalcaterra.com/blog/uncs-football-stadium-memorial-to-the-leader-of-a-white-supremacist-massacre |accessdate=October 12, 2018}} In 2018 the University decided to remove the plaque on the stadium mentioning him, and to designate the stadium as named for his son [[William R. Kenan Jr.]]{{cite news |title=Folt announces recontextualization of Kenan Memorial Stadium |date=October 3, 2018 |newspaper=[[Daily Tar Heel]] |first1=Bailey |last1=Aldridge |first2=Chris |last2=Hilburn-Trenkle |url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2018/10/kenan-stadium-name-change-breaking-folt-rename-unc-football-chapel-hill-wilmington-massacre}} ==Interesting facts== [[File:Scoreboard at Kenan Memorial Stadium.jpg|thumb|The original video board, replaced in the 2011 expansion]] *The largest crowd to see a game at Kenan—and the largest to see a game on-campus in the state of North Carolina—was a standing-room-only throng of 62,000 when the Tar Heels hosted the Florida State Seminoles in 1997. The largest paid crowd was a crowd of 62,000 that saw the Tar Heels face Duke in 2013. *Part of the 1987-88 project were a permanent lighting system, a chancellor's lounge on the north side of the field and a football lettermen's lounge on the south side. The lights are part of a General Electric low-mount system which minimizes the height of the lightpoles. Cost of the entire project was $7 million. It was funded by private gifts and bonds. *The 1991 season opener versus Cincinnati and the Clemson game, which was televised nationally by ESPN, were UNC's first true night home games in school history. *The stadium's [[sightline|sight lines]] have always been very good. The field is approximately four feet below the stands, and the rise to the stands is very steep. The west end zone seats are only 20-feet from the field, and the sideline seats are only 50-feet from the field. However, before construction of the Blue Zone several seats in the corners of the north and south stands were directly behind bushes, making it difficult to see the field. Also, people sitting in the last row of the lower level grandstand seats can't see the scoreboards or video boards because of the upper-deck overhang. *Most of the west end zone and three sections of the south stands are reserved for students. The [[student section]] of the west end zone is popularly known as the "Tar Pit"—a name applied to the entire stadium during the late 1990s. *From 2007 to 2010, fireworks were shot from atop Kenan Field House whenever the Tar Heels took the field, as well as after every score and win. They were removed in 2011, but reinstated in 2012 after [[Larry Fedora]]'s arrival, and for the next three seasons were shot off behind the west end zone. *While tickets are not nearly as hard to find as those for the basketball team, the Tar Heels sold out every game from 1992 to 1999, and also sold out all but one game of [[Butch Davis]]'s tenure. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.goheels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SITE=UNC&DB_OEM_ID=3350&ATCLID=205912861 Kenan Memorial Stadium Information] (from official UNC athletic site) *[https://maps.google.com/maps?q=chapel+hill&ll=35.906780,-79.047961&spn=0.004441,0.007298&t=h&hl=en Satellite photo of Kenan Memorial Stadium] {{North Carolina Tar Heels football navbox}} {{University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill}} {{Atlantic Coast Conference football venue navbox}} {{North Carolina college football venues}} {{Triangle sports venues}} [[Category:American football venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:North Carolina Tar Heels football]] [[Category:North Carolina Tar Heels sports venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1927]] [[Category:1927 establishments in North Carolina]]

{{Infobox Venue | stadium_name = Lamar Soccer Complex | broke_ground = June 15, 2009 | image = Lamar Soccer Complex - Stadium Grandstands.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Soccer Complex - View toward the grandstands | location = On Rolfe Christopher Dr north of US 69, 96, 287 Freeway (Cardinal Drive)
[[Beaumont, Texas]] | coordinates = {{coord|30|02|01.3|N|94|04|19.1|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | built = 2009 | opened = September 25, 2009 | record_attendance = 695
October 27, 2017
vs [[McNeese State Cowboys and Cowgirls|McNeese State]] | owner = [[Lamar University]] | operator = [[Lamar University]] | surface = grass | scoreboard = electronic, digital | seating_type = bleacher bench | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]3,724,920{{cite web|title=MINUTES OF THE BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE TEXAS STATE UNIVERSITY SYSTEM|url=http://gato-docs.its.txstate.edu/tsus/meeting-minutes/Minutes-Regular-FEBRUARY-2011-wrkg/February%2010-11%20-%20Quarterly%20Meeting.pdf|publisher=Texas State University System|accessdate=May 8, 2018|page=169|date=February 11, 2011}} | dimensions = 115 X 70 yards | architect = Leo A Daly | main_contractors = Pepper-Lawson Construction | seating_capacity = 500 | tenants = [[Lamar Lady Cardinals soccer]] ([[NCAA]]) }} The '''Lamar Soccer Complex''', built in 2009 on the campus of [[Lamar University]], is a [[Association football|soccer]] facility located in [[Beaumont, Texas|Beaumont]], [[Texas]]. It is the home stadium for the [[Division I (NCAA)]] Lamar Lady Cardinals soccer team. The [[stadium]] has a permanent [[seating capacity]] of 500. Stadium features include covered benches for both the home and visiting teams, lighting, and a programmable fertilization and irrigation system.{{cite web|title=LU Soccer Complex|url=http://lamarcardinals.com/facilities/?id=7|publisher=Lamar Cardinals Athletics|accessdate=May 6, 2018}} Construction of the stadium began on June 15, 2009. Construction cost of the soccer field and adjacent Lamar Soccer and Softball Complex building was $3,724,920. The stadium and supporting '''Lamar Soccer and Softball Complex''' building were part of a $29 million athletic construction project.{{cite web|author1=Lee Yobbi|title=Lamar soccer complex soon to be under construction|url=https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/sports/lamar/article/Lamar-soccer-complex-soon-to-be-under-construction-741812.php|publisher=[[Hearst Newspapers II, LLC]]|accessdate=May 6, 2018|date=June 11, 2009}} The first match at the new stadium was a 2-1 loss against the [[New Mexico State Aggies]] on September 25, 2009. Official attendance for the opening game was 512.{{cite web|title=New Mexico State Stuns Lamar On Soccer Complex's Opening Night|url=http://lamarcardinals.com/news/2009/9/25/New_Mexico_State_Stuns_Lamar_On_Soccer_Complex_s_Opening_Night.aspx?path=wsoc|publisher=Lamar University Athletics|accessdate=May 6, 2018|date=September 25, 2009}} ==Post Season play== The stadium served as the site of the 2014 and [[2018 Southland Conference Women's Soccer Tournament|2018]] Southland Conference soccer tournaments.{{cite web|title=2014 Soccer Championship Central 2014 Southland Soccer Tournament|url=http://southland.org/sports/2014/9/26/WSOC_0926145923.aspx|publisher=Southland Conference|accessdate=May 6, 2018}}{{cite web |title=2018 Southland Conference Soccer Tournament |url=https://southland.org/sports/2018/8/30/2018SOCChamps.aspx |publisher=Southland Conference |accessdate=October 30, 2018}} == Yearly attendance == Below is the Lady Cardinals' yearly home attendance at the Lamar Soccer Complex. {| class="wikitable" |- ! |} The attendance record of 695 was set vs [[McNeese State Cowboys and Cowgirls|McNeese State]] on October 27, 2017. ==Lamar Soccer and Softball Complex building== The Lamar Soccer and Softball Complex building is located in between the soccer stadium and the [[Lamar Softball Complex]]. The building, over 11,000 square feet in size, serves both softball and soccer. It includes coaches offices, academic study areas, laundry facilities, equipment storage, home and visitor locker rooms, concessions, public restrooms, and a training facility, one of four training facilities on campus. {{Gallery |title=Soccer Complex Pictures |width=400 |height=250 |lines=3 |align=center |File:Lamar Soccer and Softball Complex Building.jpg|alt1=Lamar Soccer and Softball Complex Building }} ==See also== *[[List of soccer stadiums in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://lamarcardinals.com/facilities/?id=7 Lamar Soccer Complex] {{Lamar University}} [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Texas]] [[Category:Sports venues in Beaumont, Texas]] [[Category:Lamar Cardinals and Lady Cardinals sports venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Lamar Lady Cardinals soccer]]

They compete in the [[Iranian Volleyball Super League]].
==History== Mizan Khorasan Volleyball Club was founded in 2010 in [[Mashhad]], [[Iran]] with the help of Khorasan Razavi Volleyball Association. Mizan first started competing in the [[Iranian Volleyball Super League|Iranian Super League]] in 2012.
==Current squad== *3. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Sahab Delghandi]] *5. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Mohsen Ekhtiarabadi]] *7. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Mojtaba Yousefi]] *8. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Mohammad Valipour]] *9. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Amir Ramshini]] *10. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Shahrouz Homayounfar]] *11. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Rahman Davoudi]] *13. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Soheil Ahmadi]] *14. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Amin Alavi]] *15. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Ebrahim Yolmeh]] *16. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Ali Jafari (volleyball)|Ali Jafari]] *17. {{Flagicon|BUL}} [[Teodor Bogdanov]] *18. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Mohammad Taher Vadi]] *19. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Sahand Allahverdian]] *20. {{Flagicon|IRN}} [[Alireza Mobasheri]] *'''Head coach''': {{flagicon|IRI}} Jabbar Ghouchannejad *'''Assistant coach''': {{Flagicon|IRN}} Bagher Soleimannejad
