{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = Val Romney | image = | country = England | fullname = Valentine Romney | nickname = | birth_date = 1718 | birth_place = Sevenoaks, Kent, England | death_date = December {{Death year and age|1773|1718}} | death_place = Sevenoaks, Kent, England | batting = unknown hand | bowling = unknown | role = batsman; team captain | club1 = [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | year1 = c.1738 to c.1753 | club2 = | year2 = | date = 29 December | year = 2009 | columns = 0 | source = F S Ashley-Cooper }}
'''Valentine "Val" Romney''' (born c.1718, probably at [[Sevenoaks]], Kent; died December 1773 at Sevenoaks) was an English [[professionalism|professional]] [[cricket]]er who played [[first-class cricket]] during the 1740s. A specialist [[batsman]], he was mainly associated with [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] but also represented [[All-England Eleven|All-England]]. Although information about his career is limited by a lack of surviving data, he is known to have made 11 [[single wicket]] and 14 first-class appearances between 1743 and 1751.
==Cricket career==
===First mention=== The first definite mention of Val Romney is dated Monday, 11 July 1743, when he took part in a single wicket "threes" match at the [[Artillery Ground]] and the six players were stated to be "the best in England".<ref name="ASW21">Ashley-Cooper, p.21.</ref> They were [[William Hodsoll]], [[John Cutbush (cricketer)|John Cutbush]] and Romney playing as Three of Kent; and [[Richard Newland (cricketer)|Richard Newland]], [[William Sawyer (cricketer)|William Sawyer]] and [[John Bryant (Kent cricketer)|John Bryant]] playing as Three of All-England. Hodsoll and Newland were the captains. Kent won by 2 runs. The ''London Evening Post'' says the crowd was computed (''sic'') to be 10,000. A return match was arranged at [[Sevenoaks Vine]] on Wednesday 27 July but "it did not come off".<ref name="ASW21"/>
===1744 to 1745=== Romney was lauded as a "mighty play'r" (''sic'') in ''Cricket, An Heroic Poem'' (1745) by [[James Love (poet)|James Love]].<ref>Love, ''Cricket, An Heroic Poem''</ref> This poem was written to commemorate a celebrated match between [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] and [[All-England Eleven|All-England]] at the [[Artillery Ground]] on 18 June 1744,<ref name="SB1">Haygarth, p.1.</ref> in which Romney was captain of the Kent XI.<ref name="U66">Underdown, p.66.</ref> In August and September of the same year, Romney played for [[London Cricket Club]] as a "given man" in three matches against [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]].<ref name="ASW36">Ashley-Cooper, p.36.</ref>
At the end of the 1744 season, Romney played in two "threes" matches at the Artillery Ground. The first was billed as "Long Robin's Side v Richard Newland's Side", the teams being [[Robert Colchin]] (''aka'' Long Robin), Romney and John Bryant against Richard Newland, [[Edward Aburrow senior]] (replacing [[John Mills (Kent cricketer)|John Mills]]) and [[Joe Harris (cricketer)|Joe Harris]]. The stake was two hundred guineas and the players involved were stated to be the "best in England".<ref name="ASW36"/> In the second match on Monday, 1 October, the sides were Colchin, [[James Bryant (Kent cricketer)|James Bryant]] and Joe Harris ''versus'' Romney, John Bryant and [[Thomas Waymark]].<ref name="ASW36"/>
In the 1745 season, Romney again played in a major "threes" match at the Artillery Ground on Monday, 24 June, when he was teamed with Hodsoll and Newland against Colchin, John Bryant and one of the Harris brothers. Hodsoll, Newland and Romney won by 7 runs.<ref name="ASW36"/> The biggest first-class match of the year took place two days later between Long Robin's XI and Richard Newland's XI at the Artillery Ground. Long Robin's XI, including Romney, won "by over 70 runs".<ref name="ASW36"/>
===1746 to 1750=== Romney is not mentioned in 1746 sources. In 1747 he played for Kent against All-England on Monday, 31 August, at the Artillery Ground; and on Wednesday, 2 September, on [[Bromley Common]].<ref name="ASW51">Ashley-Cooper, p.51.</ref> On Saturday, 5 September, there was a "threes" game at the Artillery Ground billed as "Long Robin's Side versus Stephen Dingate's Side". The teams were Colchin, [[John Harris (Surrey cricketer)|John Harris]] and Romney against [[Stephen Dingate]], Richard Newland and [[Thomas Jure]]. It was played for sixty guineas per side and the players were specially chosen from those who had played in the two Kent v All-England games.<ref name="ASW51"/>
In 1748, Romney is recorded in two single wicket matches. On Monday, 8 August, he and Colchin opposed [[Tom Faulkner]] and Joe Harris at "twos" in the Artillery Ground for twenty guineas a side.<ref name="ASW52">Ashley-Cooper, p.52.</ref> On Monday, 29 August, he took part in a "fives" game at the Artillery Ground in which Tom Faulkner's Side defeated Long Robin's Side by four runs. The prize was 200 pounds. Romney was badly injured and could not run but, the rules being "play or pay", he was obliged to play as well as he could. The teams were Faulkner, Joe Harris, James Bryant, John Bryant and [[Durling (Surrey cricketer)|Durling]] versus Colchin, Romney, [[John Larkin (cricketer)|John Larkin]], [[Jones (Kent cricketer)|Jones]] and [[Maynard (Surrey cricketer)|Maynard]].<ref name="ASW52"/>
In 1749, Romney made first-class appearances for All-England against Surrey at [[Dartford Brent]] and for Long Robin's XI against Stephen Dingate's XI at the [[Artillery Ground]]. In July he played for All-England in a "fives" match" against [[Addington Cricket Club|Addington]].<ref name="ASW53">Ashley-Cooper, p.53.</ref> There is just one mention of Romney in 1750 when he played in the Kent side that defeated Surrey by 3 wickets in a first-class match at Dartford Brent.<ref name="ASW68">Ashley-Cooper, p.68.</ref>
===Last known season=== 1751 is Romney's last known season although he may have continued for a few years more. Surviving data about matches in the 1750s is scarce. There was a general reduction in matches through the decade caused initially by the deaths of key patrons and then compounded by the impact of the [[Seven Years' War]]. Romney made two first-class appearances in May 1751 when he played for Kent against All-England. Kent, weakened by the recent death of [[Robert Colchin]], were well beaten in both games.<ref name="ASW68"/>
Val Romney's last recorded appearance was in a single wicket "fives" match for Kent against Surrey at the Artillery Ground on Monday, 3 June 1751. The Kent team was Tom Faulkner (given man), [[John Bell (Kent cricketer)|John & Thomas Bell]], [[Stone (1751 Kent cricketer)|Stone]] and Romney. The Surrey team was Stephen Dingate, John Harris, Joe Harris, [[Stephen Harding (cricketer)|Stephen Harding]] and [[Perry (Surrey cricketer)|Perry]]. Kent won "although the betting was in favour of Surrey".<ref name="DC26">Waghorn, p.26.</ref>
===Cricket in Romney's time=== In Romney's career, the [[cricket bat]] was shaped like a modern hockey stick, this being the ideal shape for addressing a ball that was "trundled" along the ground, as in [[lawn bowls]]. The [[wicket]] consisted of two stumps and a single bail. Bowlers used the [[underarm bowling|underarm]] style exclusively but at varying pace. The ball was either rolled along the ground or, if a fast bowler, skimmed across the surface; pitching was not introduced until about 1760, which would have been after Romney retired.
==Legacy== [[F S Ashley-Cooper]] says of Romney that "he was a most famous player, his name being found in nearly all the great matches of his time" and that "as a batsman and single wicket player he was very celebrated".<ref name="ASW84">Ashley-Cooper, p.84.</ref>
==Personal life== Romney lived mostly at Sevenoaks and was employed by the [[Lionel Sackville, 1st Duke of Dorset|1st Duke of Dorset]] as head gardener at [[Knole House]], a post later occupied by [[John Minshull]]. By 1768, the Sackvilles still rewarded him with a Christmas gratuity of two guineas.<ref name="U70">Underdown, p.70.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/77/77431/77431.html ''CricketArchive'' profile of Val Romney] * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153248/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1741.html#romney |date=10 October 2012 |title=From Lads to Lord's – Val Romney }}
==Bibliography== * [[F S Ashley-Cooper]], ''At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742–1751'', Cricket Magazine, 1900 * [[G B Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'', Cotterell, 1935 * [[Arthur Haygarth]], ''Scores & Biographies'', Volume 1 (1744–1826), Lillywhite, 1862 * [[James Love (poet)|James Love]], ''Cricket, An Heroic Poem'' (ed. [[F. S. Ashley-Cooper]]), Richards, 1922 * [[David Underdown]], ''Start of Play'', Allen Lane, 2000 * [[H T Waghorn]], ''The Dawn of Cricket'', Electric Press, 1906

{{Infobox Basketball club | color1 = #FFFFFF | color2 = #FF0000 | name = ŽKK Radnički Kragujevac | nickname = | logo = | imagesize = | leagues = [[First Women's Basketball League of Serbia|Serbian League]] | founded = 1967 | arena = Hall Gordana Goca Bogojević
(capacity: 600) | location = [[Kragujevac]], [[Serbia]] | colors = Red and White
{{Color box|red|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#FFFFFF|border=darkgray}} | president = {{flagicon|SRB}} ?? | coach = {{flagicon|SRB}} [[Nenad Milovanović (basketball)|Nenad Milovanović]] | championships = }} '''Ženski košarkaški klub Radnički Kragujevac''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Женски кошаркашки клуб Раднички Крагујевац}}, {{lang-en|Women's Basketball Club Radnički Kragujevac}}) is a [[Serbia]]n women's basketball team from [[Kragujevac]], [[Serbia]]. The club currently plays in [[First Women's Basketball League of Serbia|Women's Serbian League]]. ==History== Decision of the '''Basketball Club Radnički''', with the approval of the Sports Association, in 1967 the Women's Club was formed.[http://www.kkradnicki.rs/strane/zkk-radnicki.html History of club] The first president was elected Professor [[Stevan Žilović]], and the coach was [[Jovan Antić]], known as ''Jova Piroćanac'', who performed the first selection. In the first year of competition the club is in Serbian league-South took last place. It was only in 1971. year, began the serious work when the coach was [[Vlastimir Kovačević]] - Batica when they formed the pioneering schools in the primary school ''Svetozar Marković'' and ''Radoje Domanović''. The separation of male and female club coming in 1986. year. ŽKK Radnički five times in the highest ranks of the competition. In [[Yugoslav Women's Basketball League|First National League Yugoslavia]] played in seasons: 1975-76, 1977–78, 1980–81 and 1986-87 (coach [[Rajko Levajac]] and [[Vlastimir Kovačević]]), and the [[First Women's Basketball League of Serbia|First A league SRJ]] 1999-00. The most famous dancer was [[Vesna Despotović]], who is dressed shirt Yugoslavia 90 times in all selections and that the 22-year-long career has 21,240 points. The first is the athlete of [[Kragujevac]] to win an Olympic medal, and the bronze medal in [[Moscow]] in 1980. year. The owner and medals from the Balkan and European Championships. In addition to the [[Vesna Despotović]] in the national team have successfully and proudly played [[Snežana Pavlović]], [[Mirjana Jovanović]], [[Gordana Bogojević]] and [[Snežana Bozinović]]. The greatest sport success in club history starts from 2008. when this small club enters the top league in Serbia, president of the club was Zvonko Ognjanovic, head coach Vladimir S. So from 2008. next 8 years the club was in the elite league of Serbia, the top place was 4th in the end of season 2012/2013. ==Arena== '''Hall Gordana Goca Bogojević''' is a multi-purpose indoor arena located in the [[Kragujevac]] and it has a capacity of 600 seats. ==Current roster== {{Empty section|date=February 2014}} Trishtan Johnson ==Notable former players== *[[Vesna Despotović]] *[[Snežana Pavlović]] *[[Mirjana Jovanović]] *[[Gordana Bogojević]] *[[Snežana Bozinović]] *[[Nikolina Milić]] ==Notable former coaches== *[[Jovan Antić]] *[[Rajko Levajac]] *[[Vlastimir Kovačević]] *[[Vesna Despotović]] ==See also== * [[KK Radnički Kragujevac]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.facebook.com/pages/%C5%BDKK-Radni%C4%8Dki-Kragujevac/516474831804187?ref=profile Profile] at Facebook * [http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Serbia/Radnicki_Kragujevac/11435?Women=1 Profile] on eurobasket.com * [http://www.srbijasport.net/tim/16876 Profile] on srbijasport.net {{First Women's Basketball League of Serbia clubs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Radnicki Kragujevac}} [[Category:Women's basketball teams in Serbia|Radnicki Kragujevac]] [[Category:Sport in Kragujevac]] [[Category:Women's basketball teams in Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Basketball teams established in 1967]] {{Europe-basketball-team-stub}} {{Serbia-sport-stub}}
